Award.AwardTitle: The ultra-warm Arctic ca. 90 million years ago
Award.AbstractNarration: The geologic history of the Arctic region records past climatic conditions that can provide insight into modern conditions and the potential for future change. The focus of this proposed work is on an excursion within the Cretaceous greenhouse world to ultra-warm conditions, approximately 90 million years ago. Evidence for both high temperature and anomalous CO2 volcanic outgassing is found in the geology of the High Arctic. The former comes in the form of a spectacular assemblage of vertebrate fossils found on Axel Heiberg Island, including large-bodied crocodile-like champsosaurs, turtles and fish. The latter is inferred by the presence of continental flood basalts and the Alpha-Mendeleev Oceanic Ridge; these features may form one of Earth's most voluminous large igneous provinces. The investigators propose multidisciplinary studies in the High Arctic to improve understanding of the absolute age and paleotemperatures associated with the vertebrate fossils (carbon and oxygen isotope analyses) and the absolute age and duration of the anomalous volcanism (radiometric age and paleomagnetic analyses). With these data, the investigators will test prior interpretations calling for high mean annual temperatures without seasonal ice, and whether contemporaneous pulses of volcanic activity could have contributed to the inferred warming by altering atmospheric CO2. The work proposed will contribute to at least one Ph.D. thesis and will involve undergraduates who will receive field training in the High Arctic and in the laboratory. The investigators also propose outreach efforts including collaboration with local K-12 schools and the use of new media to disseminate results of their study to the general public.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Understanding the nature of past climate can provide insight to the present-day and future Earth. Our studies have focused on an exceptional episode of warmth 90 million years ago recorded in geologic strata of the High Arctic. The aim of our work was to test the veracity of interpretations calling for high mean annual temperatures without seasonal Arctic ice. We also sought to explore the hypothesis that contemporaneous pulses of volcanism could have contributed to the inferred warmth by increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide levels.

 

Our work was centered on two expeditions to remote areas of the High Arctic on Axel Heiberg and Ellesmere Islands. During the expeditions, the PI led undergraduates and graduate students in geological field instruction, paleontological collection and geophysical data collection.  

 

Amongst our findings was the discovery of fossils of a large ornithine bird we named Tingmiatornis arctica, which we reported in an open access publication in Scientific Reports. This name was derived from the Inukitut work Tingmiat, meaning “those that fly”. This bird adds further context to the ecosystem 90 million years ago which included large bodied champsosaurs, turtles and fish. Tingmiatornis is a cousin of all living birds and given its antiquity it also contributes to ideas (such as rapid growth) about how this line of birds survived the Cretaceous-Paleogene extinctions some 66 million years ago. The report of Tingmiatornis was accompanied by great interest in the media, including an article in the New York Times.

 

We have also obtained isotopic data that confirm and extend our prior inferences of high paleotemperatures in the Arctic 90 million years ago. In addition, we have new radiometric age data that suggest volcanic activity in the Arctic was coeval with the episode of extreme climate warmth, strengthening the idea that volcanic carbon dioxide outgassing caused the extreme warmth.

 

The work supported the PhD studies of Richard Bono (presently posdoctoral fellow at University of Liverpool) and BS studies of several undergraduates who have subsequently entered graduate programs across the US.
